1â†’# OFM API Documentation
     2â†’
     3â†’RESTful API for Office Facility Management System
     4â†’
     5â†’**Base URL**: `http://localhost:5174/api/v1`
     6â†’
     7â†’**Authentication**: Bearer token (JWT from Aksara SSO) or Session cookie
     8â†’
     9â†’---
    10â†’
    11â†’## ğŸ“‹ Response Format
    12â†’
    13â†’All API responses follow this standard format:
    14â†’
    15â†’```json
    16â†’{
    17â†’  "success": true|false,
    18â†’  "data": { ... },
    19â†’  "error": {
    20â†’    "code": "ERROR_CODE",
    21â†’    "message": "Error description",
    22â†’    "details": { ... }
    23â†’  },
    24â†’  "meta": {
    25â†’    "page": 1,
    26â†’    "limit": 20,
    27â†’    "total": 100,
    28â†’    "timestamp": "2025-10-16T10:00:00.000Z"
    29â†’  }
    30â†’}
    31â†’```
    32â†’
    33â†’### Error Codes
    34â†’
    35â†’- `UNAUTHORIZED` - Authentication required
    36â†’- `FORBIDDEN` - Insufficient permissions
    37â†’- `NOT_FOUND` - Resource not found
    38â†’- `VALIDATION_ERROR` - Input validation failed
    39â†’- `DUPLICATE_ERROR` - Duplicate entry
    40â†’- `INTERNAL_ERROR` - Server error
    41â†’- `BAD_REQUEST` - Invalid request
    42â†’- `CONFLICT` - Resource conflict
    43â†’
    44â†’---
    45â†’
    46â†’## ğŸš— Transportation Module
    47â†’
    48â†’### Create Transport Request
    49â†’
    50â†’**POST** `/transport/requests`
    51â†’
    52â†’Create a new transportation request (company car or voucher).
    53â†’
    54â†’**Body:**
    55â†’```json
    56â†’{
    57â†’  "type": "company_car" | "voucher",
    58â†’  "pickup": {
    59â†’    "address": "Jakarta Office",
    60â†’    "latitude": -6.2088,
    61â†’    "longitude": 106.8456
    62â†’  },
    63â†’  "destination": {
    64â†’    "address": "Surabaya Office",
    65â†’    "latitude": -7.2575,
    66â†’    "longitude": 112.7521
    67â†’  },
    68â†’  "scheduledTime": "2025-10-20T09:00:00Z",
    69â†’  "returnTime": "2025-10-20T17:00:00Z",
    70â†’  "isRoundTrip": true,
    71â†’  "passengerCount": 2,
    72â†’  "passengers": ["colleague@example.com"],
    73â†’  "purpose": "Business meeting",
    74â†’  "priority": "medium",
    75â†’  "specialRequirements": "Need wheelchair accessible vehicle"
    76â†’}
    77â†’```
    78â†’
    79â†’**Response:** `201 Created`
    80â†’```json
    81â†’{
    82â†’  "success": true,
    83â†’  "data": {
    84â†’    "_id": "507f1f77bcf86cd799439011",
    85â†’    "requestNumber": "TR-20251020-1234",
    86â†’    "status": "pending",
    87â†’    ...
    88â†’  }
    89â†’}
    90â†’```
    91â†’
    92â†’### List Transport Requests
    93â†’
    94â†’**GET** `/transport/requests`
    95â†’
    96â†’List all transportation requests with filters.
    97â†’
    98â†’**Query Parameters:**
    99â†’- `page` (number, default: 1)
   100â†’- `limit` (number, default: 20, max: 100)
   101â†’- `status` (pending | approved | rejected | cancelled | completed)
   102â†’- `type` (company_car | voucher)
   103â†’- `startDate` (ISO 8601)
   104â†’- `endDate` (ISO 8601)
   105â†’- `userId` (string, admin only)
   106â†’
   107â†’**Response:** `200 OK`
   108â†’
   109â†’### Get Request Details
   110â†’
   111â†’**GET** `/transport/requests/:id`
   112â†’
   113â†’Get detailed information about a specific request.
   114â†’
   115â†’**Response:** `200 OK`
   116â†’
   117â†’### Update Request
   118â†’
   119â†’**PATCH** `/transport/requests/:id`
   120â†’
   121â†’Update request status (approve/reject/cancel).
   122â†’
   123â†’**Body (Admin - Approve):**
   124â†’```json
   125â†’{
   126â†’  "status": "approved",
   127â†’  "vehicleId": "507f1f77bcf86cd799439012",

   146â†’
   147â†’**Response:** `200 OK`
   148â†’
   149â†’### Delete Request
   150â†’
   151â†’**DELETE** `/transport/requests/:id`
   152â†’
   153â†’Cancel a request (soft delete).
   154â†’
   155â†’**Response:** `200 OK`
   156â†’

   158â†’
   159â†’## ğŸš™ Driver Module

   162â†’
   163â†’**GET** `/driver/assignments`
   164â†’

   175â†’    "date": "2025-10-20",
   176â†’    "driverId": "user123",

1â†’# Database Setup Guide
     2â†’
     3â†’## MongoDB Atlas Setup
     4â†’
     5â†’### 1. Database Configuration
     6â†’
     7â†’The application is configured to connect to MongoDB Atlas. The connection string is stored in `.env`:
     8â†’
     9â†’```env
    10â†’MONGODB_URI=mongodb+srv://root:pass123word@devday.wmveufv.mongodb.net/?retryWrites=true&w=majority&appName=DevDay
    11â†’MONGODB_DB=ofm_dev
    12â†’```
    13â†’
    14â†’### 2. Database will be automatically created
    15â†’
    16â†’MongoDB Atlas will **automatically create** the database (`ofm_dev`) when you run the seed script. You don't need to manually create it in Atlas.
    17â†’
    18â†’## Seeding the Database
    19â†’
    20â†’### Run the seed script:
    21â†’
    22â†’```bash
    23â†’bun run db:seed
    24â†’```
    25â†’
    26â†’This will:
    27â†’1. Connect to MongoDB Atlas
    28â†’2. Create the `ofm_dev` database (if it doesn't exist)
    29â†’3. Clear existing data in all collections
    30â†’4. Insert mock data
    31â†’
    32â†’### What gets seeded:
    33â†’
    34â†’**Organizations:**
    35â†’- 1 Company (Indonesian Aviation Services - IAS)
    36â†’- 2 Locations (Jakarta, Surabaya)
    37â†’
    38â†’**Users & Permissions:**
    39â†’- 4 Roles (Super Admin, Admin, Employee, Driver)
    40â†’- 3 Users:
    41â†’  - `admin@ias.co.id` (Super Admin)
    42â†’  - `john.doe@ias.co.id` (Employee)
    43â†’  - `jane.smith@ias.co.id` (Employee)
    44â†’
    45â†’**Transportation:**
    46â†’- 4 Vehicles (SUV, Sedan, MPV, BYD EV)
    47â†’- 2 Drivers
    48â†’- 3 Vouchers (Gojek, Grab)
    49â†’- 2 Sample bookings
    50â†’
    51â†’**Meeting Rooms:**

    53â†’- 2 Sample bookings
    54â†’
    55â†’## Database Collections
    56â†’
    57â†’The following collections will be created:
    58â†’
    59â†’### Organization
    60â†’- `companies` - Company information
    61â†’- `users` - User accounts
    62â†’- `roles` - User roles and permissions
    63â†’- `locations` - Office locations
    64â†’
    65â†’### Transportation
    66â†’- `vehicles` - Company vehicles
    67â†’- `drivers` - Company drivers
    68â†’- `transportation_requests` - Car bookings
    69â†’- `vouchers` - Transportation vouchers
    70â†’- `voucher_allocations` - Voucher assignments
    71â†’- `vehicle_tracking` - GPS data
    72â†’- `obd_data` - Vehicle diagnostics
    73â†’
    74â†’### Meeting Rooms
    75â†’- `meeting_rooms` - Available rooms
    76â†’- `meeting_requests` - Room booking requests (unified collection for all meeting bookings, **includes embedded attendees array**)
    77â†’- `meeting_licenses` - Video conferencing licenses
    78â†’- `facilities` - Room facilities
    79â†’
    80â†’## Key Schema Structures
    81â†’
    82â†’### Meeting Requests with Attendance
    83â†’
    84â†’The `meeting_requests` collection stores meeting bookings AND attendance as an embedded array:
    85â†’
    86â†’```javascript
    87â†’{
    88â†’  _id: ObjectId,
    89â†’  title: String,              // Meeting title
    90â†’  roomId: String,             // Custom room identifier (e.g., "R101")
    91â†’  organizerId: String,
    92â†’  participants: [{
    93â†’    userId: String,           // NIK (Nomor Induk Karyawan)
    94â†’    email: String,
    95â†’    name: String
    96â†’  }],
    97â†’  startTime: Date,
    98â†’  endTime: Date,
    99â†’  status: String,
   100â†’  // Attendance tracking (embedded array)
   101â†’  attendees: [{
   102â†’    type: String,             // "internal" | "external"
   103â†’    userId: String,           // NIK for internal, null for external
   104â†’    name: String,             // Employee or guest name
   105â†’    email: String,            // Email address
   106â†’    checkinTime: Date,        // When they checked in
   107â†’    method: String            // "qr" | "manual"
   108â†’  }],
   109â†’  createdAt: Date,
   110â†’  updatedAt: Date
   111â†’}
   112â†’```
   113â†’
   114â†’**Field Notes:**
   115â†’- `userId` in users collection = NIK (Nomor Induk Karyawan / Employee ID Number)
   116â†’- `roomId` in meeting_rooms = Custom identifier like "R101", "CONF-A" (NOT MongoDB _id)
   117â†’- `attendees` array supports both internal employees and external guests
   118â†’- No invitation requirement for check-in - anyone can attend
   119â†’
   120â†’## Verifying the Data
   121â†’
   122â†’After seeding, you can verify the data in MongoDB Atlas:
   123â†’
   124â†’1. Go to https://cloud.mongodb.com
   125â†’2. Navigate to your cluster
   126â†’3. Click "Browse Collections"
   127â†’4. Select the `ofm_dev` database
   128â†’5. Browse through the collections
   129â†’
   130â†’## Re-seeding
   131â†’
   132â†’To reset the database with fresh mock data:
   133â†’
   134â†’```bash
   135â†’bun run db:seed
   136â†’```
   137â†’
   138â†’**âš ï¸ Warning:** This will delete ALL existing data and replace it with mock data.
   139â†’
   140â†’## Production Deployment
   141â†’
   142â†’For production:
   143â†’
   144â†’1. Create a separate production database in MongoDB Atlas
   145â†’2. Update `.env` with production credentials
   146â†’3. **DO NOT** run the seed script in production
   147â†’4. Use proper migration scripts instead
   148â†’
   149â†’## Sample Credentials
   150â†’
   151â†’After seeding, you can login with:
   152â†’
   153â†’- **Admin:** `admin@ias.co.id` / `admin123`
   154â†’- **Employee:** `john.doe@ias.co.id` / `password123`
   155â†’- **Employee:** `jane.smith@ias.co.id` / `password123`
   156â†’
   157â†’Note: Passwords are hashed in the database. Authentication will be implemented in the next phase.
   158â†’

1â†’# Data Synchronization Strategy: SSO â†” OFM

    10â†’

    23â†’                  â”‚

    27â†’â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

    30â†’â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
    31â†’â”‚  Collections:                                           â”‚

    37â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    38â†’```
    39â†’
    40â†’---
    41â†’
    42â†’## Data Sync Rules
    43â†’
    44â†’### 1. Organizations/Companies
    45â†’
    46â†’**Source**: SSO `organizations` collection
    47â†’**OFM Storage**: Not stored, fetched on-demand
    48â†’**Access**: Via `/api/companies` â†’ proxies to SSO `/api/organizations`
    49â†’
    50â†’**Why on-demand?**
    51â†’- SSO is the single source of truth
    52â†’- Org structure changes should immediately reflect in OFM
    53â†’- No risk of stale data
    54â†’
    55â†’**User Field Mapping:**
    56â†’```javascript
    57â†’// In SSO:
    58â†’employee.organizationId = "ORG001"
    59â†’
    60â†’// In OFM user record:
    61â†’user.companyId = "ORG001"  // Same value, different field name
    62â†’```
    63â†’
    64â†’---
    65â†’
    66â†’### 2. Departments/Org Units
    67â†’
    68â†’**Source**: SSO `org_units` collection
    69â†’**OFM Storage**: Not stored, fetched on-demand
    70â†’**Access**: Via `/api/departments` â†’ proxies to SSO `/api/org-units`
    71â†’
    72â†’**Why on-demand?**
    73â†’- Organizational restructuring is common
    74â†’- SSO manages the hierarchy (parent/child relationships)
    75â†’- OFM only needs to reference, not manage
    76â†’
    77â†’**User Field Mapping:**
    78â†’```javascript
    79â†’// In SSO:
    80â†’employee.orgUnitId = ObjectId("...")
    81â†’
    82â†’// In OFM user record:
    83â†’user.departmentId = "..." // Same ObjectId as string
    84â†’```
    85â†’
    86â†’---
    87â†’
    88â†’### 3. Positions
    89â†’
    90â†’**Source**: SSO `positions` collection
    91â†’**OFM Storage**: Not stored, fetched on-demand
    92â†’**Access**: Could add `/api/positions` if needed (not yet implemented)
    93â†’
    94â†’**User Field Mapping:**
    95â†’```javascript
    96â†’// In SSO:
    97â†’employee.positionId = ObjectId("...")
    98â†’
    99â†’// In OFM user record:
   100â†’user.positionId = "..." // Same ObjectId as string
   101â†’```
   102â†’
   103â†’---
   104â†’
   105â†’### 4. Locations (Physical Office Locations)
   106â†’
   107â†’**Source**: **OFM-managed** (NOT from SSO)
   108â†’**OFM Storage**: `locations` collection
   109â†’**Reason**:
   110â†’
   111â†’SSO has `workLocation` field (text like "Jakarta HQ"), but:
   112â†’- Meeting rooms are at specific physical buildings
   113â†’- OFM needs structured location data (address, coordinates, etc.)
   114â†’- Work location â‰  meeting room location (e.g., remote workers)
   115â†’
   116â†’**Structure:**
   117â†’```javascript
   118â†’{
   119â†’  _id: ObjectId("..."),
   120â†’  locationId: "LOC-JKT-01",
   121â†’  name: "Jakarta Head Office",
   122â†’  address: "Jl. Sudirman No. 123",
   123â†’  city: "Jakarta",
   124â†’  province: "DKI Jakarta",
   125â†’  country: "Indonesia",
   126â†’  latitude: -6.2088,
   127â†’  longitude: 106.8456,
   128â†’  isActive: true
   129â†’}
   130â†’```
   131â†’
   132â†’**User Assignment:**
   133â†’- Admin manually assigns users to OFM locations via `/modules/users`
   134â†’- Used for meeting room booking (show rooms at user's location first)
   135â†’
   136â†’---
   137â†’
   138â†’### 5. Employees/Users
   139â†’
   140â†’**Source**: SSO `employees` collection
   141â†’**OFM Storage**: **Synced to** `users` collection
   142â†’**Sync Method**:
   143â†’- **On Login**: Individual user synced via `syncUserFromSSO()`
   144â†’- **Bulk Sync**: Run `scripts/sync-employees-from-sso.ts` to sync all
   145â†’
   146â†’**Why sync instead of on-demand?**
   147â†’- Users need OFM-specific data (roleIds, locationId, etc.)
   148â†’- Manager relationships need to reference OFM user._id
   149â†’- Approval workflows need to query user data quickly
   150â†’- Booking history tied to OFM user records
   151â†’
   152â†’**User Record Structure:**
   153â†’```javascript
   154â†’{
   155â†’  _id: ObjectId("..."),              // OFM user ID
   156â†’  ssoUserId: "68f1e89...",           // Link to SSO user._id
   157â†’  userId: "12345",                   // Employee ID / NIK
   158â†’  email: "john.doe@ias.co.id",
   159â†’  username: "john.doe",
   160â†’  firstName: "John",
   161â†’  lastName: "Doe",
   162â†’  phone: "+62-811-1234-5678",
   163â†’
   164â†’  // From SSO (synced on login):
   165â†’  companyId: "ORG001",               // organizationId from SSO
   166â†’  departmentId: "68f123...",         // orgUnitId from SSO
   167â†’  positionId: "68f456...",           // positionId from SSO
   168â†’
   169â†’  // OFM-managed:
   170â†’  locationId: "68f789...",           // OFM location._id (manually assigned)
   171â†’  managerId: "68fabc...",            // OFM user._id (NOT SSO userId)
   172â†’  roleIds: ["68fdef..."],            // OFM role._id references
   173â†’
   174â†’  isActive: true,
   175â†’  createdAt: Date,
   176â†’  updatedAt: Date
   177â†’}
   178â†’```
   179â†’
   180â†’---
   181â†’
   182â†’### 6. Manager Relationships
   183â†’
   184â†’**Challenge**: SSO has `managerId` but it references SSO `user._id`, not OFM `user._id`
   185â†’
   186â†’**Solution**: Two-step sync process
   187â†’
   188â†’**Step 1** - Sync all employees:
   189â†’```bash
   190â†’bun run scripts/sync-employees-from-sso.ts
   191â†’```
   192â†’- Creates OFM user for every SSO employee
   193â†’- Initially stores SSO `userId` in OFM `user.managerId`
   194â†’
   195â†’**Step 2** - Fix manager references:
   196â†’```javascript
   197â†’// Script automatically maps SSO userId â†’ OFM user._id
   198â†’const ssoToOfmMap = Map<string, string>
   199â†’ssoToOfmMap.set(ssoUserId, ofmUser._id)
   200â†’
   201â†’// Update all users
   202â†’user.managerId = ssoToOfmMap.get(employee.managerId)
   203â†’```
   204â†’
   205â†’**Result**:
   206â†’- `user.managerId` now references another OFM `user._id`
   207â†’- Can query managers directly: `db.users.findOne({ _id: user.managerId })`
   208â†’
   209â†’---
   210â†’
   211â†’### 7. Roles & Permissions
   212â†’
   213â†’**Source**: **OFM-only** (NOT in SSO)
   214â†’**Storage**: `roles` collection
   215â†’**Reason**: SSO handles authentication, OFM handles authorization
   216â†’
   217â†’**Role Structure:**
   218â†’```javascript
   219â†’{
   220â†’  _id: ObjectId("68f20c1b..."),
   221â†’  roleId: "super_admin",             // Unique role identifier
   222â†’  roleName: "Super Administrator",
   223â†’  description: "Full system access",
   224â†’  permissions: [
   225â†’    "transportation.create",
   226â†’    "transportation.approve",
   227â†’    "meeting.create",
   228â†’    "admin.users.manage",
   229â†’    // ... 40+ permissions
   230â†’  ],
   231â†’  isActive: true
   232â†’}
   233â†’```
   234â†’
   235â†’**User-Role Mapping:**
   236â†’```javascript
   237â†’// In OFM user record:
   238â†’user.roleIds = [
   239â†’  "68f20c1b3ab7bbf6679726bd",      // Reference to roles._id
   240â†’  "68f20c1b3ab7bbf6679726be"
   241â†’]
   242â†’```
   243â†’
   244â†’**Default Role Assignment:**
   245â†’- New users (on first login): `employee` role
   246â†’- Special case: `admin@ias.co.id` â†’ `super_admin` role
   247â†’- Admins can assign additional roles via `/modules/users`
   248â†’
   249â†’---
   250â†’
   251â†’## Sync Operations
   252â†’
   253â†’### 1. On User Login (Automatic)
   254â†’
   255â†’**Trigger**: Every OAuth 2.0 login
   256â†’**Function**: `syncUserFromSSO()` in `/lib/server/auth/sync.ts`
   257â†’**Process**:
   258â†’
   259â†’```javascript
   260â†’1. User logs in via SSO
   261â†’2. Get userInfo from /oauth/userinfo (includes all SSO employee data)
   262â†’3. Check if user exists in OFM by ssoUserId
   263â†’4. If exists:
   264â†’   - Update firstName, lastName, phone, companyId, departmentId, positionId
   265â†’   - Keep existing roleIds, locationId, managerId
   266â†’5. If new:
   267â†’   - Create new user with SSO data
   268â†’   - Assign default role (employee)
   269â†’   - locationId and managerId are null (admin assigns later)
   270â†’6. Load user's roleIds from OFM roles collection
   271â†’7. Create session with complete user data
   272â†’```
   273â†’
   274â†’**Limitations**:
   275â†’- Only syncs the logged-in user
   276â†’- Manager might not exist in OFM yet (if they haven't logged in)
   277â†’
   278â†’### 2. Bulk Employee Sync (Manual)
   279â†’
   280â†’**When to run**:
   281â†’- Initial setup
   282â†’- After organizational changes (new hires, transfers)
   283â†’- When manager relationships are needed
   284â†’
   285â†’**Command**:
   286â†’```bash
   287â†’bun run scripts/sync-employees-from-sso.ts
   288â†’```
   289â†’
   290â†’**Process**:
   291â†’```javascript
   292â†’1. Connect to both SSO and OFM databases
   293â†’2. Fetch all active employees from SSO
   294â†’3. For each employee:
   295â†’   - Check if exists in OFM (by email or ssoUserId)
   296â†’   - Create or update user record
   297â†’4. Build map: SSO userId â†’ OFM user._id
   298â†’5. Fix all managerId references to point to OFM user._id
   299â†’```
   300â†’
   301â†’**Result**:
   302â†’- All employees exist in OFM
   303â†’- Manager relationships are correct
   304â†’- Users dropdown shows all employees for manager selection
   305â†’
   306â†’---
   307â†’
   308â†’## Data Flow Examples
   309â†’
   310â†’### Example 1: New Employee First Login
   311â†’
   312â†’```
   313â†’1. Employee "jane.smith@ias.co.id" clicks "Login with SSO"
   314â†’2. OAuth redirects to SSO login page
   315â†’3. Employee enters credentials (in SSO)
   316â†’4. SSO authenticates and redirects back with code
   317â†’5. OFM exchanges code for access token
   318â†’6. OFM calls /oauth/userinfo with token
   319â†’7. SSO returns:
   320â†’   {
   321â†’     sub: "68f123...",
   322â†’     email: "jane.smith@ias.co.id",
   323â†’     employeeId: "EMP001",
   324â†’     firstName: "Jane",
   325â†’     lastName: "Smith",
   326â†’     organizationId: "ORG001",
   327â†’     orgUnitId: "DEPT001",
   328â†’     positionId: "POS001",
   329â†’     managerId: "68f999..." // SSO userId of manager
   330â†’   }
   331â†’8. OFM runs syncUserFromSSO()
   332â†’9. User doesn't exist, so create:
   333â†’   {
   334â†’     _id: ObjectId("68faaa..."),  // NEW OFM ID
   335â†’     ssoUserId: "68f123...",
   336â†’     userId: "EMP001",

   353â†’
   354â†’### Example 2: Admin Assigns Location and Manager
   355â†’
   356â†’```
   357â†’1. Admin opens /modules/users
   358â†’2. Clicks "Edit" on Jane Smith
   359â†’3. Modal loads dropdowns:

   361â†’   - Departments: fetched from /api/departments (SSO data)
   362â†’   - Locations: fetched from /api/v1/locations (OFM data)
   363â†’   - Manager: fetched from /api/users (OFM data - all synced employees)
   364â†’   - Roles: fetched from /api/v1/roles (OFM data)
   365â†’4. Admin selects:
   366â†’   - Location: "Jakarta HQ" (68floc...)
   367â†’   - Manager: "John Doe" (68fmgr...)
   368â†’   - Roles: [Super Admin, Employee]
   369â†’5. Saves â†’ PUT /api/users/68faaa...
   370â†’6. OFM updates:

   373â†’     managerId: "68fmgr...",     // Now OFM user._id (correct!)
   374â†’     roleIds: ["68fadmin...", "68femployee..."]
   375â†’   }
   376â†’```
   377â†’
   378â†’---
   379â†’
   380â†’## API Endpoints Reference
   381â†’
   382â†’### SSO APIs (called by OFM)
   383â†’
   384â†’| Endpoint | Method | Purpose | Called By |
   385â†’|----------|--------|---------|-----------|
   386â†’| `/oauth/authorize` | GET | Initiate login | User browser |
   387â†’| `/oauth/token` | POST | Exchange code for tokens | OFM backend |
   388â†’| `/oauth/userinfo` | GET | Get logged-in user data | OFM backend (on login) |
   389â†’| `/api/organizations` | GET | List companies | OFM `/api/companies` |
   390â†’| `/api/org-units` | GET | List departments | OFM `/api/departments` |
   391â†’| `/api/positions` | GET | List positions | (Not yet used) |
   392â†’
   393â†’### OFM APIs
   394â†’
   395â†’| Endpoint | Method | Purpose | Data Source |
   396â†’|----------|--------|---------|-------------|
   397â†’| `/api/companies` | GET | List companies | Proxy to SSO |
   398â†’| `/api/departments` | GET | List departments | Proxy to SSO |
   399â†’| `/api/v1/locations` | GET | List locations | OFM database |
   400â†’| `/api/users` | GET | List users | OFM database (synced from SSO) |
   401â†’| `/api/users/[id]` | PUT | Update user | OFM database |
   402â†’| `/api/v1/roles` | GET | List roles | OFM database |

   406â†’## Best Practices

   408â†’### 1. Initial Setup

   410â†’```bash

   419â†’
   420â†’# Step 4: Fix role IDs (if migrating from old structure)
   421â†’bun run scripts/fix-user-roleids.ts
   422â†’```
   423â†’
   424â†’### 2. Regular Operations
   425â†’
   426â†’- **New employees**: Automatically synced on first login
   427â†’- **Employee updates**: Automatically synced on each login
   428â†’- **Org structure changes**: Immediately reflected (on-demand from SSO)
   429â†’- **Manager changes**: Re-run bulk sync if needed
   430â†’
   431â†’### 3. Data Consistency
   432â†’
   433â†’**What's always up-to-date**:
   434â†’- âœ… Employee names, phone, email (synced on login)
   435â†’- âœ… Company/department/position (synced on login)

   438â†’**What requires manual admin work**:

   440â†’- âš™ï¸ Role assignment (OFM-specific)
   441â†’- âš™ï¸ Manager relationships (initially from SSO, can be overridden)
   442â†’
   443â†’---
   444â†’
   445â†’## Troubleshooting
   446â†’
   447â†’### Issue: Manager dropdown shows no options
   448â†’
   449â†’**Cause**: Managers haven't logged in yet, so they don't exist in OFM
   450â†’**Fix**: Run bulk employee sync
   451â†’```bash

   453â†’```
   454â†’
   455â†’### Issue: Department/Company dropdown shows nothing
   456â†’
   457â†’**Cause**: SSO API call failed or auth token expired
   458â†’**Check**: Browser console for 401/404 errors
   459â†’**Fix**: Re-login to get fresh access token

   472â†’**Fix**: Run duplicate fix script

   474â†’bun run scripts/fix-duplicate-users.ts
   475â†’```
   476â†’
   477â†’---
   478â†’
   479â†’## Future Enhancements
   480â†’
   481â†’### 1. SCIM Employee Sync (Planned)
   482â†’
   483â†’Instead of bulk sync script, implement SCIM protocol:

   497â†’- Background job to keep manager relationships in sync
   498â†’

   501â†’## Summary
   502â†’
   503â†’| Data | Source | Storage | Sync Method |
   504â†’|------|--------|---------|-------------|
   505â†’| Companies | SSO | On-demand | API proxy |
   506â†’| Departments | SSO | On-demand | API proxy |
   507â†’| Positions | SSO | On-demand | API proxy |
   508â†’| **Locations** | **OFM** | **OFM DB** | **Manual** |
   509â†’| Employees | SSO | OFM DB | On login + bulk sync |

   512â†’
   513â†’**Key Principle**: SSO owns employee and org data, OFM owns operational data (roles, locations, bookings).

1â†’# QR Code & Attendance System
     2â†’
     3â†’## âœ… Changes Made
     4â†’
     5â†’### **1. Replaced External QR Code API with Internal Generator**
     6â†’
     7â†’**Before:**
     8â†’- Used external API: `https://api.qrserver.com/v1/create-qr-code/`
     9â†’- Required internet connection
    10â†’- Privacy concern: Room URLs sent to external service
    11â†’- Slower (network latency)
    12â†’
    13â†’**After:**
    14â†’- Internal QR code generation using `qrcode` library
    15â†’- Works completely offline âœ…
    16â†’- Secure: No data sent externally âœ…
    17â†’- Faster: Generated client-side âœ…
    18â†’
    19â†’### **2. Redesigned Check-In System for Meeting Attendance**
    20â†’
    21â†’**Before:**
    22â†’- One QR code for booking
    23â†’- Manual check-in button (unclear purpose)
    24â†’
    25â†’**After:**
    26â†’- **Two QR codes** with different purposes:
    27â†’  1. **Quick Book** - When no meeting (for booking the room)
    28â†’  2. **Mark Attendance** - When meeting active (for attendance)
    29â†’- **Manual Entry button** - Fallback for participants without QR scanner
    30â†’
    31â†’---
    32â†’
    33â†’## ğŸ—ï¸ Architecture
    34â†’
    35â†’### QR Code Component
    36â†’
    37â†’**Location:** `src/lib/components/QRCode.svelte`
    38â†’
    39â†’**Features:**
    40â†’- Reusable Svelte component
    41â†’- Canvas-based rendering
    42â†’- Configurable size, colors, error correction
    43â†’- Reactive: Updates when value changes
    44â†’- Error handling with fallback UI
    45â†’
    46â†’**Usage:**
    47â†’```svelte
    48â†’<QRCode
    49â†’  value="https://example.com/page"
    50â†’  size={200}
    51â†’  errorCorrectionLevel="M"
    52â†’  darkColor="#000000"
    53â†’  lightColor="#ffffff"
    54â†’  margin={1}
    55â†’/>
    56â†’```
    57â†’
    58â†’**Props:**
    59â†’| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
    60â†’|------|------|---------|-------------|
    61â†’| `value` | string | required | Data to encode |
    62â†’| `size` | number | 200 | Width/height in pixels |
    63â†’| `errorCorrectionLevel` | 'L'\|'M'\|'Q'\|'H' | 'M' | Error correction level |
    64â†’| `margin` | number | 1 | Quiet zone size |
    65â†’| `darkColor` | string | '#000000' | Dark module color |
    66â†’| `lightColor` | string | '#ffffff' | Light module color |
    67â†’

     3â†’This guide explains how to set up SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management) integration between Aksara SSO and OFM for automatic user and organizational data synchronization.
     4â†’

    14â†’---
    15â†’
    16â†’## Overview
    17â†’
    18â†’### What is SCIM?
    19â†’
    20â†’SCIM 2.0 is an industry-standard REST API protocol for automated user provisioning and identity management. It eliminates the need for manual data entry and ensures your OFM database stays synchronized with Aksara SSO.
    21â†’
    22â†’### Benefits
    23â†’
    24â†’- âœ… **Automatic User Sync**: New employees automatically appear in OFM
    25â†’- âœ… **Real-time Updates**: Changes in SSO instantly reflected in OFM via webhooks
    26â†’- âœ… **Organizational Structure**: Complete sync of companies, departments, positions
    27â†’- âœ… **Deactivation**: Employees leaving the company are automatically deactivated
    28â†’- âœ… **No Manual Work**: Set it and forget it
    29â†’
    30â†’### Architecture
    31â†’
    32â†’```
    33â†’â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

    39â†’               â”‚

    41â†’               â”‚
    42â†’â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â–¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

    47â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    48â†’```

   190â†’## Webhook Configuration
   191â†’
   192â†’Webhooks provide **instant synchronization** without polling. When a user is created, updated, or deleted in Aksara SSO, OFM receives an immediate notification.
   193â†’
   194â†’### Step 1: Register Webhook in Aksara SSO
   195â†’
   196â†’1. In Aksara SSO, go to **SCIM Clients** â†’ Your client â†’ **Webhooks**
   197â†’2. Click **"Add Webhook"**
   198â†’3. Configure:
   199â†’   - **Webhook URL**: `http://localhost:5174/api/v1/scim/webhook` (use your actual domain in production)
   200â†’   - **Events**: Select all:
   201â†’     - `user.created`
   202â†’     - `user.updated`
   203â†’     - `user.deleted`
   204â†’     - `group.created`
   205â†’     - `group.updated`
   206â†’     - `group.deleted`
   207â†’   - **Secret**: Use the same value as `SCIM_WEBHOOK_SECRET` from your `.env`
   208â†’   - **Max Retries**: `3`
   209â†’   - **Retry Delay**: `1000` ms
   210â†’4. Click **"Save"**
   211â†’
   212â†’### Step 2: Test Webhook
   213â†’
   214â†’1. In Aksara SSO, update a user (e.g., change phone number)
   215â†’2. Check OFM server logs, you should see:
   216â†’   ```
   217â†’   ğŸ“¥ Webhook received: user.updated (User)
   218â†’   âœ… User updated via webhook: john.doe@ias.co.id
   219â†’   ```
   220â†’3. Verify the change in OFM database
   221â†’
   222â†’### Webhook Security
   223â†’
   224â†’Webhooks are secured using **HMAC SHA-256 signatures**. Every webhook request includes an `X-SCIM-Signature` header:
   225â†’
   226â†’```
   227â†’X-SCIM-Signature: sha256=abc123def456...
   228â†’```
   229â†’
   230â†’OFM automatically verifies this signature using `SCIM_WEBHOOK_SECRET`. Invalid signatures are rejected with `401 Unauthorized`.
   231â†’
   232â†’**Never expose your webhook secret publicly!**
   233â†’

   267â†’## Sync Behavior
   268â†’
   269â†’### Initial Sync
   270â†’
   271â†’When you run the first sync:
   272â†’- All users from SSO are **created** in OFM
   273â†’- All organizational units are **created** in OFM
   274â†’- Default role (`employee` or `super_admin`) is assigned based on email
   275â†’
   276â†’### Subsequent Syncs
   277â†’
   278â†’- **Existing users**: Updated with latest SSO data
   279â†’- **New users in SSO**: Created in OFM
   280â†’- **Deactivated users in SSO**: Marked as `isActive: false` in OFM
   281â†’- **Deleted users in SSO**: Marked as `isActive: false` in OFM (soft delete)
   282â†’
   283â†’### Conflict Resolution
   284â†’
   285â†’- SCIM data **always wins** during sync
   286â†’- Local changes to user data (made in OFM) will be **overwritten**
   287â†’- To preserve local data, exclude those fields from sync mapping
   288â†’

   291â†’## Monitoring & Logging
   292â†’
   293â†’### Sync History
   294â†’
   295â†’Every sync operation is logged to the `syncHistory` collection:
   296â†’
   297â†’```javascript
   298â†’{
   299â†’  type: 'scim_full_sync',

   311â†’}

   313â†’
   314â†’### Webhook Events

   329â†’
   330â†’### View Logs in MongoDB

   333â†’// Last 10 syncs

   335â†’

   344â†’```
   345â†’

   348â†’## Quick Reference
   349â†’
   350â†’### Common Commands
   351â†’
   352â†’```bash
   353â†’# Manual sync (run from project root)
   354â†’bun run sync:scim
   355â†’
   356â†’# Test SCIM connection

   360â†’curl -X POST http://localhost:5173/scim/v2/token \
   361â†’  -d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
   362â†’  -d "client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID" \
   363â†’  -d "client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET"
   364â†’
   365â†’# Fetch users manually (with token from above)
   366â†’curl http://localhost:5173/scim/v2/Users \
   367â†’  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN"
   368â†’
   369â†’# Fetch groups manually
   370â†’curl http://localhost:5173/scim/v2/Groups \
   371â†’  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN"
   372â†’```
   373â†’
   374â†’### Scheduled Sync (Production)
   375â†’
   376â†’#### Linux/macOS - Crontab
   377â†’
   378â†’Add to crontab (`crontab -e`):
   379â†’
   380â†’```bash
   381â†’# Sync every 6 hours
   382â†’0 */6 * * * cd /path/to/ofm && bun run sync:scim >> /var/log/ofm-scim.log 2>&1
   383â†’
   384â†’# Or sync daily at 2 AM
   385â†’0 2 * * * cd /path/to/ofm && bun run sync:scim >> /var/log/ofm-scim.log 2>&1
   386â†’```
   387â†’
   388â†’#### Windows - Task Scheduler
   389â†’
   390â†’1. Open Task Scheduler
   391â†’2. Create Basic Task
   392â†’3. Configure:
   393â†’   - **Program**: `bun`
   394â†’   - **Arguments**: `run sync:scim`
   395â†’   - **Start in**: `C:\path\to\ofm`
   396â†’   - **Trigger**: Daily at 2:00 AM (or every 6 hours)
   397â†’   - **Conditions**: Only if network is available
   398â†’4. Save and test
   399â†’
   400â†’---
   401â†’
   402â†’## Troubleshooting
   403â†’
   404â†’### Error: "SCIM_CLIENT_ID and SCIM_CLIENT_SECRET must be set"
   405â†’
   406â†’**Cause**: Environment variables not configured.
   407â†’
   408â†’**Solution**:
   409â†’1. Check `.env` file exists in project root
   410â†’2. Verify `SCIM_CLIENT_ID` and `SCIM_CLIENT_SECRET` are set
   411â†’3. Restart OFM server after editing `.env`
   412â†’
   413â†’### Error: "Failed to get access token"
   414â†’
   415â†’**Cause**: Invalid client credentials or SSO not running.
   416â†’
   417â†’**Solution**:
   418â†’1. Verify Aksara SSO is running: `curl http://localhost:5173/health`
   419â†’2. Check SCIM client credentials in SSO admin console
   420â†’3. Test token endpoint manually:
   421â†’   ```bash
   422â†’   curl -X POST http://localhost:5173/scim/v2/token \
   423â†’     -d "grant_type=client_credentials" \
   424â†’     -d "client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID" \
   425â†’     -d "client_secret=YOUR_SECRET"
   426â†’   ```
   427â†’
   428â†’### Error: "Connection Failed"
   429â†’
   430â†’**Possible causes**:
   431â†’- Aksara SSO not running
   432â†’- Wrong `SSO_BASE_URL` in `.env`
   433â†’- Firewall blocking connection
   434â†’- Network issues
   435â†’
   436â†’**Solution**:
   437â†’1. Ping SSO: `curl http://localhost:5173/scim/v2/ServiceProviderConfig`
   438â†’2. Check firewall rules
   439â†’3. Verify URL in `.env` matches SSO address
   440â†’
   441â†’### Error: "Invalid webhook signature"
   442â†’
   443â†’**Cause**: Webhook secret mismatch between SSO and OFM.
   444â†’
   445â†’**Solution**:
   446â†’1. Ensure `SCIM_WEBHOOK_SECRET` in OFM `.env` matches the secret used in SSO webhook configuration
   447â†’2. Regenerate webhook secret and update both SSO and OFM
   448â†’
   449â†’### Users Not Syncing
   450â†’
   451â†’**Debugging steps**:
   452â†’1. Check sync history: `db.syncHistory.find().sort({ completedAt: -1 }).limit(1)`
   453â†’2. Look for errors in `stats.errors` array
   454â†’3. Check user `isActive` status in SSO (only active users synced by default)
   455â†’4. Manually fetch users via SCIM API:
   456â†’   ```bash
   457â†’   curl http://localhost:5173/scim/v2/Users \
   458â†’     -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_TOKEN"
   459â†’   ```
   460â†’
   461â†’### Webhook Not Working
   462â†’
   463â†’**Debugging steps**:
   464â†’1. Check webhook is registered in SSO admin console
   465â†’2. Verify `SCIM_WEBHOOK_SECRET` is set in `.env`
   466â†’3. Check OFM server logs for webhook events
   467â†’4. Test webhook manually:
   468â†’   ```bash
   469â†’   curl -X POST http://localhost:5174/api/v1/scim/webhook \
   470â†’     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   471â†’     -H "X-SCIM-Signature: sha256=test" \
   472â†’     -d '{"event":"user.updated","resourceType":"User",...}'
   473â†’   ```
   474â†’5. Check `webhookEvents` collection for delivery failures
   475â†’
   476â†’---
   477â†’
   478â†’## Best Practices
   479â†’
   480â†’### Security
   481â†’
   482â†’- âœ… Use HTTPS in production (required for webhooks)
   483â†’- âœ… Rotate SCIM client secret every 90 days
   484â†’- âœ… Use IP whitelisting in production
   485â†’- âœ… Store secrets in environment variables, never in code
   486â†’- âœ… Enable webhook signature verification
   487â†’
   488â†’### Performance
   489â†’
   490â†’- âœ… Run full sync during off-peak hours (e.g., 2 AM)
   491â†’- âœ… Use webhooks for real-time updates instead of frequent polling
   492â†’- âœ… Monitor sync duration and optimize if > 5 minutes
   493â†’- âœ… Use pagination for large datasets (count=1000 max)
   494â†’
   495â†’### Reliability
   496â†’
   497â†’- âœ… Schedule periodic full sync as backup (every 12-24 hours)
   498â†’- âœ… Monitor sync failures and set up alerts
   499â†’- âœ… Keep sync history for auditing (at least 30 days)
   500â†’- âœ… Test sync in staging before production deployments
   501â†’
   502â†’### Maintenance
   503â†’
   504â†’- âœ… Review sync errors weekly
   505â†’- âœ… Clean up old sync history logs monthly
   506â†’- âœ… Validate data integrity quarterly
   507â†’- âœ… Keep SCIM client library up to date
   508â†’
   509â†’---
   510â†’
   511â†’## FAQ
   512â†’
   513â†’**Q: How often should I run full sync?**
   514â†’A: If using webhooks, once every 12-24 hours as backup. Without webhooks, every 4-6 hours.
   515â†’
   516â†’**Q: What happens if sync fails?**
   517â†’A: The error is logged to `syncHistory` collection. Users continue using cached data until next successful sync.
   518â†’
   519â†’**Q: Can I customize which fields are synced?**
   520â†’A: Yes, edit `/src/lib/server/scim/sync.ts` and modify the field mappings.
   521â†’
   522â†’**Q: Will local user changes be overwritten?**
   523â†’A: Yes, SCIM data always wins. Don't edit user data in OFM if you want to preserve it.
   524â†’
   525â†’**Q: Can I sync only specific users?**
   526â†’A: Yes, use SCIM filters. Example: `filter=department eq "507f..."` in the fetch call.
   527â†’
   528â†’**Q: How do I handle deleted users?**
   529â†’A: Deleted users are soft-deleted (marked inactive). To hard-delete, create a cleanup script.
   530â†’
   531â†’**Q: What if SSO is down during sync?**
   532â†’A: Sync will fail and log the error. Users continue using cached data. Next sync will retry.
   533â†’
   534â†’**Q: Can I use SCIM with multiple SSO instances?**
   535â†’A: Not currently. OFM connects to one SSO instance. For multi-tenant, use separate OFM deployments.
   536â†’

   545â†’

   548â†’## Support
   549â†’
   550â†’For issues or questions:
   551â†’1. Check this documentation
   552â†’2. Review OFM server logs
   553â†’3. Check Aksara SSO documentation
   554â†’4. File an issue on GitHub

    58â†’## Usage

    72â†’
    73â†’#### Get a Setting
    74â†’
    75â†’```typescript
    76â†’import { getSetting } from '$lib/server/settings';
    77â†’
    78â†’const scimBaseUrl = await getSetting('scim.base_url');
    79â†’```
    80â†’
    81â†’#### Get SCIM Config
    82â†’
    83â†’```typescript
    84â†’import { getSCIMConfig } from '$lib/server/settings';
    85â†’
    86â†’const config = await getSCIMConfig();
    87â†’// { baseUrl, clientId, clientSecret, webhookSecret }
    88â†’```
    89â†’
    90â†’#### Update a Setting
    91â†’
    92â†’```typescript
    93â†’import { updateSetting } from '$lib/server/settings';
    94â†’
    95â†’await updateSetting('scim.client_id', 'new-client-id', userId);
    96â†’```
    97â†’
    98â†’## Settings Categories
    99â†’
   100â†’### SCIM Integration (`scim`)
   101â†’
   102â†’| Key | Label | Type | Required |
   103â†’|-----|-------|------|----------|
   104â†’| `scim.base_url` | SSO Base URL | text | Yes |
   105â†’| `scim.client_id` | SCIM Client ID | text | Yes |
   106â†’| `scim.client_secret` | SCIM Client Secret | secret | Yes |
   107â†’| `scim.webhook_secret` | SCIM Webhook Secret | secret | No |
   108â†’
   109â†’### Email Settings (`email`)
   110â†’
   111â†’| Key | Label | Type | Required |
   112â†’|-----|-------|------|----------|
   113â†’| `email.smtp_host` | SMTP Host | text | No |
   114â†’| `email.smtp_port` | SMTP Port | text | No |
   115â†’| `email.smtp_user` | SMTP Username | text | No |
   116â†’| `email.smtp_password` | SMTP Password | secret | No |
   117â†’
   118â†’### General Settings (`general`)
   119â†’
   120â†’| Key | Label | Type | Required |
   121â†’|-----|-------|------|----------|
   122â†’| `general.app_name` | Application Name | text | Yes |
   123â†’| `general.app_url` | Application URL | text | Yes |
   124â†’
   125â†’## Security
   126â†’
   127â†’### Encryption
   128â†’
   129â†’- **Algorithm**: AES-256-CBC
   130â†’- **Key Source**: `SETTINGS_ENCRYPTION_KEY` environment variable
   131â†’- **Key Length**: 32 bytes (padded if needed)
   132â†’- **IV**: Random 16 bytes per encrypted value
   133â†’- **Format**: `{iv}:{encrypted_data}` (hex-encoded)
   134â†’
   135â†’### API Security
   136â†’
   137â†’- **Authentication**: Required for all endpoints
   138â†’- **Authorization**: Admin role recommended (not enforced yet)
   139â†’- **Input Validation**: Settings must match predefined keys
   140â†’- **Output Masking**: Secrets displayed as `***HIDDEN***`
   141â†’
   142â†’## API Endpoints
   143â†’
   144â†’### GET /api/v1/settings
   145â†’
   146â†’Get settings by category.
   147â†’
   148â†’**Query Parameters**:
   149â†’- `category` (required): `scim`, `email`, or `general`
   150â†’
   151â†’**Response**:
   152â†’```json
   153â†’{
   154â†’  "success": true,
   155â†’  "data": [
   156â†’    {
   157â†’      "key": "scim.base_url",
   158â†’      "value": "http://localhost:5173",
   159â†’      "category": "scim",
   160â†’      "label": "SSO Base URL",
   161â†’      "isSecret": false,
   162â†’      "isRequired": true
   163â†’    }
   164â†’  ]
   165â†’}
   166â†’```
   167â†’
   168â†’### PUT /api/v1/settings
   169â†’
   170â†’Update multiple settings.
   171â†’
   172â†’**Request Body**:
   173â†’```json
   174â†’{
   175â†’  "settings": [
   176â†’    {
   177â†’      "key": "scim.client_id",
   178â†’      "value": "new-client-id"
   179â†’    },
   180â†’    {
   181â†’      "key": "scim.client_secret",
   182â†’      "value": "new-client-secret"
   183â†’    }
   184â†’  ]
   185â†’}
   186â†’```
   187â†’
   188â†’**Response**:
   189â†’```json
   190â†’{
   191â†’  "success": true,
   192â†’  "message": "Settings updated successfully"
   193â†’}
   194â†’```
   195â†’
   196â†’### POST /api/v1/scim/test
   197â†’
   198â†’Test SCIM connection using current settings.
   199â†’
   200â†’**Response** (Success):
   201â†’```json
   202â†’{
   203â†’  "success": true,
   204â†’  "message": "Successfully connected to Aksara SSO SCIM API",
   205â†’  "details": {
   206â†’    "supportsBulk": true,
   207â†’    "supportsFilter": true,
   208â†’    "maxResults": 200
   209â†’  }
   210â†’}
   211â†’```
   212â†’
   213â†’**Response** (Error):
   214â†’```json
   215â†’{
   216â†’  "success": false,
   217â†’  "message": "Failed to get access token (401): Invalid credentials"
   218â†’}
   219â†’```
   220â†’
   221â†’## Database Schema
   222â†’
   223â†’```typescript
   224â†’interface Setting {
   225â†’  _id?: ObjectId;
   226â†’  key: string;              // Unique key (e.g., 'scim.client_id')
   227â†’  value: string;            // Encrypted if isSecret = true
   228â†’  category: string;         // 'scim' | 'email' | 'general' | 'auth'
   229â†’  label: string;            // Human-readable label
   230â†’  description?: string;     // Help text
   231â†’  isSecret: boolean;        // Whether to encrypt
   232â†’  isRequired: boolean;      // Whether required
   233â†’  updatedBy?: string;       // User ID who last updated
   234â†’  updatedAt: Date;
   235â†’  createdAt: Date;
   236â†’}
   237â†’```
   238â†’
   239â†’## Initialization
   240â†’
   241â†’Settings are automatically initialized on server startup:
   242â†’
   243â†’1. Server starts â†’ `hooks.server.ts` â†’ `initializeDB()`
   244â†’2. `initializeDB()` â†’ `initializeSettings()`
   245â†’3. `initializeSettings()` â†’ Insert default settings if not exist
   246â†’4. SCIM client uses `getConfig()` â†’ Reads from database with 1-minute cache
   247â†’
   248â†’## Migration from .env
   249â†’
   250â†’If you have existing `.env` settings, they will still work as fallback:
   251â†’
   252â†’1. Database setting (highest priority)
   253â†’2. `env` module from `$env/dynamic/private`
   254â†’3. `process.env` (lowest priority)
   255â†’
   256â†’To migrate:
   257â†’
   258â†’1. Go to Settings page
   259â†’2. Enter your credentials from `.env`
   260â†’3. Save settings
   261â†’4. (Optional) Remove from `.env` file
   262â†’
   263â†’## Troubleshooting
   264â†’
   265â†’### Settings not taking effect
   266â†’
   267â†’**Solution**: Wait 1 minute for cache to expire, or restart the server.
   268â†’
   269â†’### SCIM test connection fails
   270â†’
   271â†’**Checklist**:
   272â†’1. Verify SSO server is running
   273â†’2. Check credentials in settings
   274â†’3. Test with curl: Settings page shows curl command for debugging
   275â†’4. Check SSO terminal for authentication errors
   276â†’
   277â†’### Encrypted values not decrypting
   278â†’
   279â†’**Cause**: `SETTINGS_ENCRYPTION_KEY` changed after values were encrypted
   280â†’
   281â†’**Solution**:
   282â†’1. Set `SETTINGS_ENCRYPTION_KEY` back to original value, OR
   283â†’2. Re-enter all secret values in Settings page
   284â†’
   285â†’## Future Enhancements
   286â†’
   287â†’- [ ] Role-based access control (only admins can edit settings)
   288â†’- [ ] Setting validation (URL format, port ranges, etc.)
   289â†’- [ ] Test email functionality
   290â†’- [ ] Audit log for settings changes
   291â†’- [ ] Backup/restore settings
   292â†’- [ ] Import/export settings as JSON
   293â†’- [ ] Setting templates for different environments
   294â†’
   295â†’## Related Documentation
   296â†’
   297â†’- [SCIM Integration Guide](DOCS/SCIM_INTEGRATION.md)
   298â†’- [Database Setup](DOCS/DATABASE.md)
   299â†’- [Settings Schema](src/lib/server/db/schemas/settings.ts)
   300â†’

    61â†’## Authentication Flow

    63â†’### 1. User Initiates Login

    84â†’### 5. User Synchronization

    92â†’- Session stored in encrypted httpOnly cookie (`ofm_session`)
    93â†’
    94â†’### 7. Automatic Token Refresh
    95â†’- On every request, `hooks.server.ts` checks session expiry
    96â†’- If expires in < 15 minutes, automatically refresh using refresh_token
    97â†’- Seamless user experience with no re-login required

   194â†’## Testing

   196â†’### 1. Start Both Servers

   250â†’- **Revocation:** On logout

   258â†’## User Synchronization

   260â†’When a user logs in via SSO for the first time:
   261â†’
   262â†’1. OFM checks if user exists locally by `ssoUserId`
   263â†’2. If not found, creates new user with:

   272â†’On subsequent logins:

   276â†’## API Reference

   278â†’### OAuth Client Functions

   330â†’## Troubleshooting

   332â†’### Issue: "Missing OAuth state or code verifier"
   333â†’- **Cause:** Cookies not persisting between redirects
   334â†’- **Solution:** Ensure browser allows cookies, check cookie settings
   335â†’
   336â†’### Issue: "Token exchange failed: 400"
   337â†’- **Cause:** Invalid code or code_verifier
   338â†’- **Solution:** Check PKCE implementation, verify redirect URI matches

   340â†’### Issue: "Session decode error"

1â†’# Image Storage Migration Guide
     2â†’
     3â†’## Current Implementation: Base64 in MongoDB
     4â†’
     5â†’Room photos are currently stored as base64-encoded strings directly in MongoDB's `meeting_rooms.imageUrl` field.
     6â†’
     7â†’**Pros:**
     8â†’- âœ… Simple implementation
     9â†’- âœ… No additional infrastructure needed
    10â†’- âœ… Works well for containerized deployments
    11â†’- âœ… Backup/restore handled by MongoDB
    12â†’
    13â†’**Cons:**
    14â†’- âš ï¸ Limited to ~500KB per image (to avoid bloating database)
    15â†’- âš ï¸ Increases MongoDB storage size
    16â†’- âš ï¸ Not ideal for high-resolution images
    17â†’- âš ï¸ All images loaded in API responses
    18â†’
    19â†’**Current Code Location:**
    20â†’- `/src/routes/admin/rooms/+page.svelte` - Upload UI and base64 conversion
    21â†’- `handleImageUpload()` function - File-to-base64 conversion logic
    22â†’
    23â†’---
    24â†’
    25â†’## Migration Path: S3-Compatible Object Storage
    26â†’
    27â†’When you're ready to scale, migrate to S3-compatible storage (AWS S3, MinIO, DigitalOcean Spaces, etc.)
    28â†’
    29â†’### Step 1: Setup Object Storage
    30â†’
    31â†’**Option A: MinIO (Self-hosted, S3-compatible)**
    32â†’```bash
    33â†’docker run -p 9000:9000 -p 9001:9001 \

    40â†’**Option B: AWS S3**

    44â†’
    45â†’### Step 2: Install S3 Client Library

    51â†’
    52â†’### Step 3: Create Storage Service
    53â†’
    54â†’Create `/src/lib/server/storage.ts`:
    55â†’
    56â†’```typescript
    57â†’import { S3Client, PutObjectCommand, GetObjectCommand } from '@aws-sdk/client-s3';
    58â†’import { getSignedUrl } from '@aws-sdk/s3-request-presigner';
    59â†’
    60â†’const s3Client = new S3Client({
    61â†’  region: process.env.S3_REGION || 'us-east-1',
    62â†’  endpoint: process.env.S3_ENDPOINT, // For MinIO
    63â†’  credentials: {

    68â†’});
    69â†’
    70â†’const BUCKET_NAME = process.env.S3_BUCKET || 'ofm-room-photos';
    71â†’
    72â†’export async function uploadImage(file: Buffer, key: string, contentType: string) {
    73â†’  const command = new PutObjectCommand({
    74â†’    Bucket: BUCKET_NAME,
    75â†’    Key: key,
    76â†’    Body: file,
    77â†’    ContentType: contentType
    78â†’  });
    79â†’
    80â†’  await s3Client.send(command);
    81â†’  return `s3://${BUCKET_NAME}/${key}`;
    82â†’}
    83â†’
    84â†’export async function getImageUrl(key: string, expiresIn = 3600) {
    85â†’  const command = new GetObjectCommand({
    86â†’    Bucket: BUCKET_NAME,
    87â†’    Key: key
    88â†’  });
    89â†’
    90â†’  // Generate signed URL valid for 1 hour
    91â†’  return await getSignedUrl(s3Client, command, { expiresIn });
    92â†’}
    93â†’```
    94â†’
    95â†’### Step 4: Create Upload API Endpoint
    96â†’
    97â†’Create `/src/routes/api/v1/upload/image/+server.ts`:
    98â†’
    99â†’```typescript
   100â†’import { json } from '@sveltejs/kit';
   101â†’import type { RequestHandler } from './$types';
   102â†’import { uploadImage } from '$lib/server/storage';
   103â†’import { requireAuth } from '$lib/server/auth';
   104â†’import { randomUUID } from 'crypto';
   105â†’
   106â†’export const POST: RequestHandler = async (event) => {
   107â†’  await requireAuth(event);
   108â†’
   109â†’  const formData = await event.request.formData();

   116â†’  // Validate file size (e.g., max 5MB for S3)

   118â†’    return json({ success: false, error: 'File too large (max 5MB)' }, { status: 400 });
   119â†’  }
   120â†’
   121â†’  // Generate unique key
   122â†’  const ext = file.name.split('.').pop();
   123â†’  const key = `rooms/${randomUUID()}.${ext}`;
   124â†’
   125â†’  // Upload to S3
   126â†’  const buffer = Buffer.from(await file.arrayBuffer());
   127â†’  const s3Path = await uploadImage(buffer, key, file.type);
   128â†’
   129â†’  return json({ success: true, data: { key, url: s3Path } });
   130â†’};

   132â†’
   133â†’### Step 5: Update Admin UI

   137â†’```typescript

   207â†’
   208â†’### Step 8: Data Migration Script
   209â†’
   210â†’Create `/scripts/migrate-images-to-s3.ts`:
   211â†’
   212â†’```typescript
   213â†’import { MongoClient } from 'mongodb';
   214â†’import { uploadImage } from '../src/lib/server/storage';
   215â†’
   216â†’async function migrateImagesToS3() {
   217â†’  const client = new MongoClient(process.env.MONGODB_URI!);
   218â†’  await client.connect();
   219â†’
   220â†’  const db = client.db(process.env.MONGODB_DB);
   221â†’  const rooms = await db.collection('meeting_rooms')
   222â†’    .find({ imageUrl: { $regex: '^data:image' } }) // Find base64 images
   223â†’    .toArray();
   224â†’
   225â†’  for (const room of rooms) {
   226â†’    try {
   227â†’      // Extract base64 data
   228â†’      const base64Data = room.imageUrl.split(',')[1];
   229â†’      const buffer = Buffer.from(base64Data, 'base64');
   230â†’
   231â†’      // Upload to S3
   232â†’      const key = `rooms/${room._id}.jpg`;
   233â†’      const s3Path = await uploadImage(buffer, key, 'image/jpeg');
   234â†’
   235â†’      // Update database

   237â†’        { _id: room._id },
   238â†’        { $set: { imageUrl: key } }
   239â†’      );
   240â†’
   241â†’      console.log(`âœ… Migrated ${room.roomName}`);
   242â†’    } catch (error) {
   243â†’      console.error(`âŒ Failed to migrate ${room.roomName}:`, error);
   244â†’    }
   245â†’  }
   246â†’
   247â†’  await client.close();
   248â†’}
   249â†’
   250â†’migrateImagesToS3();
   251â†’```
   252â†’

   259â†’
   260â†’## Comparison
   261â†’
   262â†’| Feature | Base64 (Current) | S3 (Future) |
   263â†’|---------|------------------|-------------|
   264â†’| Setup Complexity | âœ… Simple | âš ï¸ Requires infrastructure |

# OFM - Office Facility Management

## About

OFM is a unified web-based system for managing employee transportation, meeting rooms, and office facilities within a multi-entity corporate environment (holding company + subsidiaries).

The system integrates with **Aksara SSO** for identity management and supports web, tablet (room displays), and planned mobile (Android) clients.

## Objectives

1. **Centralize office operations** - Single platform for transportation requests, meeting room bookings, and facility/supply requests across all entities and locations
2. **Enable self-service** - Employees request resources directly; admins approve and manage via dashboard
3. **Improve visibility** - Real-time tracking of vehicles, room availability, and resource utilization
4. **Support multi-entity** - Holding company with subsidiaries, regional scoping, consolidated reporting
5. **Reduce manual work** - Automated approval workflows, driver assignment, voucher allocation, and employee sync from SSO

## Tech Stack

| Layer | Technology |
|-------|-----------|
| Backend | SvelteKit + TypeScript + Bun |
| Frontend | Svelte 5 (Runes API) |
| Database | MongoDB Atlas |
| Auth | Aksara SSO (OAuth 2.0 / OIDC) + SCIM 2.0 |
| Maps | Leaflet.js + OpenStreetMap |
| Room Display | Tablet / Raspberry Pi |
| Mobile (planned) | Kotlin + Jetpack Compose |

**Ports:** Aksara SSO = `5173`, OFM = `5174`

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TB
    subgraph "Client Layer"
        WEB[Web App - Svelte 5]
        DRIVER[Driver Android App - Planned]
        EMP[Employee Android App - Planned]
        TABLET[Room Display - Tablet/RasPi]
    end

    subgraph "Backend Layer"
        SSO[Aksara SSO - OAuth 2.0 / OIDC - :5173]
        API[OFM API Server - SvelteKit - :5174]
    end

    subgraph "Data Layer"
        MONGO[(MongoDB Atlas)]
    end

    WEB -->|HTTPS| API
    DRIVER -->|HTTPS + GPS| API
    EMP -->|HTTPS| API
    TABLET -->|HTTPS| API

    WEB -.->|OAuth Login| SSO
    DRIVER -.->|OAuth Login| SSO
    EMP -.->|OAuth Login| SSO

    API --> MONGO
```

## Module Index

Each module has a code (M1-M9) used consistently across all documentation and the backlog tracker.

| Code | Module | Description | Doc |
|------|--------|-------------|-----|
| M1 | Authentication | SSO login, OAuth 2.0, session management | [M1-authentication](modules/M1-authentication.md) |
| M2 | Admin | Master data management, system configuration | [M2-admin](modules/M2-admin.md) |
| M3 | Dashboard | Overview statistics, monitoring, quick actions | [M3-dashboard](modules/M3-dashboard.md) |
| M4 | Meeting | Room booking, calendar, attendance/check-in | [M4-meeting](modules/M4-meeting.md) |
| M5 | Transportation | Car/voucher requests, driver assignment, tracking | [M5-transportation](modules/M5-transportation.md) |
| M6 | Room Display | Tablet/RasPi display, QR codes, service worker | [M6-room-display](modules/M6-room-display.md) |
| M7 | API | Backend REST API (`/api/v1/*`), 22+ endpoint groups | [M7-api](modules/M7-api.md) |
| M8 | Facility | Office supply requests, inventory (planned) | [M8-facility](modules/M8-facility.md) |
| M9 | Mobile Apps | Android driver app, employee app (planned) | [M9-mobile](modules/M9-mobile.md) |

**Sub-module codes** use dot notation: `M2.1` (Devices), `M4.1` (Book), `M5.3` (Tracking), etc.

Technical documentation (database, dev standards, reusables) lives in `technical/`.

## Status Tracking

For detailed status of every module, sub-module, route, and test coverage:

**[backlog/target.csv](backlog/target.csv)**

Status values: `done`, `partial`, `planned`, `issue`

## User Roles

| Role | Access |
|------|--------|
| Super Admin | Full system access |
| Global Admin | Multi-entity access |
| Regional Admin | Location-specific |
| Employee | Request and view own bookings |
| Driver | View assignments, confirm trips |

## Business Rules

### Transportation
- Cancellation re-enables car as available
- After-hours requires advance booking
- Voucher providers: Gojek, Grab (managed via admin)

### Meeting Rooms
- Max duration: 8 hours
- Recurring meetings: require Super Admin approval
- Cancellation: requires re-approval from admin
- Room capacity validated against participant count

## Open Decisions

These design questions are pending finalization:

| # | Question | Recommendation |
|---|----------|---------------|
| 1 | How to deliver voucher codes to employees? | Email + web app + push notification |
| 2 | When to notify drivers about assignments? | Immediately + reminder 2 hours before |
| 3 | Auto-offer voucher when car unavailable? | Admin decides, system suggests |
| 4 | How to mark trip as completed? | Driver confirms + auto-complete after 12h |
| 5 | Do all meetings need approval? | Configurable per room |

## Development Phases

| Phase | Focus | Status |
|-------|-------|--------|
| 1 | API Foundation (22+ modules) | Done |
| 2 | Mobile Infrastructure (auth, WebSocket, GPS) | Planned |
| 3 | Android Driver App | Planned |
| 4 | Android Employee App | Planned |
| 5 | Admin Approval Workflows | Planned |
| 6 | Advanced Features (multi-entity, reporting, OBD-II) | Planned |

## Development Guidelines

- Check `technical/reusables.md` before writing new code (20+ reusable modules)
- Keep files under ~500 lines
- Use Svelte 5 syntax (`onclick` not `on:click`)
- Use standardized API response format and REST patterns
- No style tags in Svelte components (global CSS only)

## Source Documents

Original documentation archived in `olds/` for reference. Conflicts between old docs have been resolved in the current module docs.

# OFM - Office Facility Management

## About

OFM is a unified web-based system for managing employee transportation, meeting rooms, and office facilities within a multi-entity corporate environment (holding company + subsidiaries).

The system integrates with **Aksara SSO** for identity management and supports web, tablet (room displays), and mobile (Android) clients.

## Objectives

1. **Centralize office operations** - Single platform for transportation requests, meeting room bookings, and facility/supply requests across all entities and locations
2. **Enable self-service** - Employees request resources directly; admins approve and manage via dashboard
3. **Improve visibility** - Real-time tracking of vehicles, room availability, and resource utilization
4. **Support multi-entity** - Holding company with subsidiaries, regional scoping, consolidated reporting
5. **Reduce manual work** - Automated approval workflows, driver assignment, voucher allocation, and employee sync from SSO

## Tech Stack

| Layer | Technology |
|-------|-----------|
| Backend | SvelteKit + TypeScript + Bun |
| Frontend | Svelte 5 (Runes API) |
| Database | MongoDB Atlas |
| Auth | Aksara SSO (OAuth 2.0 / OIDC) + SCIM 2.0 |
| Maps | Leaflet.js + OpenStreetMap |
| Room Display | Tablet / Raspberry Pi |
| Mobile (planned) | Kotlin + Jetpack Compose |

**Ports:** Aksara SSO = `5173`, OFM = `5174`

## Architecture

```mermaid
graph TB
    subgraph "Client Layer"
        WEB[Web App - Svelte 5]
        DRIVER[Driver Android App - Planned]
        EMP[Employee Android App - Planned]
        TABLET[Room Display - Tablet/RasPi]
    end

    subgraph "Backend Layer"
        SSO[Aksara SSO - OAuth 2.0 / OIDC - :5173]
        API[OFM API Server - SvelteKit - :5174]
    end

    subgraph "Data Layer"
        MONGO[(MongoDB Atlas)]
    end

    WEB -->|HTTPS| API
    DRIVER -->|HTTPS + GPS| API
    EMP -->|HTTPS| API
    TABLET -->|HTTPS| API

    WEB -.->|OAuth Login| SSO
    DRIVER -.->|OAuth Login| SSO
    EMP -.->|OAuth Login| SSO

    API --> MONGO
```

## Module Index

Each module has a code (M1-M9) used consistently across all documentation and the backlog tracker.

| Code | Module | Description | Doc |
|------|--------|-------------|-----|
| M1 | Authentication | SSO login, OAuth 2.0, session management | [M1-authentication](modules/M1-authentication.md) |
| M2 | Admin | Master data management, system configuration | [M2-admin](modules/M2-admin.md) |
| M3 | Dashboard | Overview statistics, monitoring, quick actions | [M3-dashboard](modules/M3-dashboard.md) |
| M4 | Meeting | Room booking, calendar, attendance/check-in | [M4-meeting](modules/M4-meeting.md) |
| M5 | Transportation | Car/voucher requests, driver assignment, tracking | [M5-transportation](modules/M5-transportation.md) |
| M6 | Room Display | Tablet/RasPi display, QR codes, service worker | [M6-room-display](modules/M6-room-display.md) |
| M7 | API | Backend REST API (`/api/v1/*`), 22+ endpoint groups | [M7-api](modules/M7-api.md) |
| M8 | Facility | Office supply requests, inventory (planned) | [M8-facility](modules/M8-facility.md) |
| M9 | Mobile Apps | Android driver app, employee app (planned) | [M9-mobile](modules/M9-mobile.md) |

**Sub-module codes** use dot notation: `M2.1` (Devices), `M4.1` (Book), `M5.3` (Tracking), etc.

Technical documentation (database, dev standards, reusables) lives in `technical/`.

## Status Tracking

For detailed status of every module, sub-module, route, and test coverage:

**[backlog/target.csv](backlog/target.csv)**

Status values: `done`, `partial`, `planned`, `issue`

## User Roles

| Role | Access |
|------|--------|
| Super Admin | Full system access |
| Global Admin | Multi-entity access |
| Regional Admin | Location-specific |
| Employee | Request and view own bookings |
| Driver | View assignments, confirm trips |

## Business Rules

### Transportation
- Cancellation re-enables car as available
- After-hours requires advance booking
- Voucher providers: Gojek, Grab (managed via admin)

### Meeting Rooms
- Max duration: 8 hours
- Recurring meetings: require Super Admin approval
- Cancellation: requires re-approval from admin
- Room capacity validated against participant count

## Open Decisions

These design questions are pending finalization:

| # | Question | Recommendation |
|---|----------|---------------|
| 1 | How to deliver voucher codes to employees? | Email + web app + push notification |
| 2 | When to notify drivers about assignments? | Immediately + reminder 2 hours before |
| 3 | Auto-offer voucher when car unavailable? | Admin decides, system suggests |
| 4 | How to mark trip as completed? | Driver confirms + auto-complete after 12h |
| 5 | Do all meetings need approval? | Configurable per room |

## Development Phases

| Phase | Focus | Status |
|-------|-------|--------|
| 1 | API Foundation (22+ modules) | Done |
| 2 | Mobile Infrastructure (auth, WebSocket, GPS) | Planned |
| 3 | Android Driver App | Planned |
| 4 | Android Employee App | Planned |
| 5 | Admin Approval Workflows | Planned |
| 6 | Advanced Features (multi-entity, reporting, OBD-II) | Planned |

## Development Guidelines

- Check `technical/reusables.md` before writing new code (20+ reusable modules)
- Keep files under ~500 lines
- Use Svelte 5 syntax (`onclick` not `on:click`)
- Use standardized API response format and REST patterns
- No style tags in Svelte components (global CSS only)

## Source Documents

Original documentation archived in `olds/` for reference. Conflicts between old docs have been resolved in the current module docs.

# OFM - Office Facility Management

## About

OFM is a unified web-based system for managing employee transportation, meeting rooms, and office facilities within a multi-entity corporate environment (holding company + subsidiaries).

The system integrates with **Aksara SSO** for identity management and supports web, tablet (room displays), and mobile (Android) clients.

## Objectives

1. **Centralize office operations** - Single platform for transportation requests, meeting room bookings, and facility/supply requests across all entities and locations
2. **Enable self-service** - Employees request resources directly; admins approve and manage via dashboard
3. **Improve visibility** - Real-time tracking of vehicles, room availability, and resource utilization
4. **Support multi-entity** - Holding company with subsidiaries, regional scoping, consolidated reporting
5. **Reduce manual work** - Automated approval workflows, driver assignment, voucher allocation, and employee sync from SSO

## Tech Stack

| Layer | Technology |
|-------|-----------|
| Backend | SvelteKit + TypeScript + Bun |
| Frontend | Svelte 5 (Runes API) |
| Database | MongoDB Atlas |
| Auth | Aksara SSO (OAuth 2.0 / OIDC) + SCIM 2.0 |
| Maps | Leaflet.js + OpenStreetMap |

## File 1: `/Users/HERIAWAN/Project/_mya/DOCS/modules/M2-admin.md`

```markdown
# M2 - Admin Panel

Administrative panel for managing master data, system settings, and operational resources. All routes are under `/admin/*`.

---

## Sub-Modules

### M2.1 Devices

Management of IoT devices used across the system (room tablets, Raspberry Pi displays).

- CRUD for device records
- Device status tracking (online/offline)
- Assignment to rooms or vehicles

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/devices` | Device list and management |

**Related:** M5 (Room Display) for tablet devices assigned to meeting rooms.

---

### M2.2 Drivers

Driver master data and availability management.

- CRUD for driver records (name, license, rating)
- Availability status (on duty / off duty)
- Assignment history

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/drivers` | Driver list and management |

**Related:** M4 (Transportation) for driver assignment to trips; M8 (Driver Android App) for mobile-side status management.

---

### M2.3 Rooms

Meeting room master data with capacity and facility details.

- CRUD for room records (name, floor, capacity, facilities)
- Room status management (available / maintenance)
- QR code generation for room tablet access

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/rooms` | Room list and management |

**Related:** M6 (Meeting Room Booking) for room reservation; M5 (Room Display) for tablet schedule display.

---

### M2.4 Settings

Database-backed configuration system with web UI. Replaces `.env`-based configuration for runtime-editable settings.

#### Architecture

```
Admin UI --> API Endpoint --> Settings Module --> MongoDB
                                   |
                            SCIM Client (with cache)
```

#### Encryption

- **Algorithm:** AES-256-CBC
- **Key source:** `SETTINGS_ENCRYPTION_KEY` environment variable
- **Key length:** 32 bytes (padded if needed)
- **IV:** Random 16 bytes per encrypted value
- **Storage format:** `{iv}:{encrypted_data}` (hex-encoded)

#### Cache Strategy

- TTL: 1 minute
- Fallback chain: Database -> env module -> process.env
- Auto-refresh on cache expiry

#### Settings Categories

**SCIM Integration (`scim`)**

| Key | Label | Type | Required |
|-----|-------|------|----------|
| `scim.base_url` | SSO Base URL | text | Yes |
| `scim.client_id` | SCIM Client ID | text | Yes |
| `scim.client_secret` | SCIM Client Secret | secret | Yes |
| `scim.webhook_secret` | SCIM Webhook Secret | secret | No |

**Email (`email`)**

| Key | Label | Type | Required |
|-----|-------|------|----------|
| `email.smtp_host` | SMTP Host | text | No |
| `email.smtp_port` | SMTP Port | text | No |
| `email.smtp_user` | SMTP Username | text | No |
| `email.smtp_password` | SMTP Password | secret | No |

**General (`general`)**

| Key | Label | Type | Required |
|-----|-------|------|----------|
| `general.app_name` | Application Name | text | Yes |
| `general.app_url` | Application URL | text | Yes |

#### API Endpoints

| Method | Endpoint | Description |
|--------|----------|-------------|
| GET | `/api/v1/settings?category={cat}` | Get settings by category |
| PUT | `/api/v1/settings` | Update multiple settings |
| POST | `/api/v1/scim/test` | Test SCIM connection |

#### Security Notes

- Secrets are displayed as `***HIDDEN***` in the UI
- Input validation: settings must match predefined keys
- Authentication required for all endpoints
- Admin role recommended (RBAC enforcement pending)

#### Key Files

```
src/routes/admin/settings/+page.svelte        # Settings UI with tabs
src/routes/admin/settings/+page.server.ts      # Load settings by category
src/routes/api/v1/settings/+server.ts          # GET/PUT settings API
src/routes/api/v1/scim/test/+server.ts         # Test SCIM connection
src/lib/server/settings.ts                     # Settings CRUD with encryption
src/lib/server/db/schemas/settings.ts          # Schema and defaults
```

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/settings` | Settings management UI (SCIM, Email, General tabs) |

**Related:** M1 (Auth/SSO) for SCIM integration settings.

---

### M2.5 Transport Companies

Management of transportation voucher providers (Gojek, Grab, etc.).

- CRUD for transport company records
- Active/inactive toggle
- Provider-specific configuration

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/transport-companies` | Transport company list and management |

**Related:** M4 (Transportation) for voucher provider selection; M2.9 (Vouchers) for voucher pool management per provider.

---

### M2.6 Trip Purpose

Master data for trip purposes, used for analytics and reporting.

- CRUD for trip purpose records
- Category assignment
- Approval flags (some purposes may require additional approval)

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/trip-purposes` | Trip purpose list and management |

**Related:** M4 (Transportation) for purpose selection in transport request forms.

---

### M2.7 Vehicles

Vehicle fleet master data management.

- CRUD for vehicle records (plate, model, capacity, type)
- Vehicle status tracking (available / in-use / maintenance)
- Driver assignment linkage

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `/admin/vehicles` | Vehicle list and management |

**Related:** M4 (Transportation) for vehicle assignment to trips.

---

### M2.8 Videos
```
